DOC.HEAD: Peter Jovanovich Named President of Publishing Giant Run By Father
DOC.TEXT: Peter Jovanovich has been promoted to president and chief executive officer at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., making him second in command after his father, HBJ Chairman William Jovanovich. The younger Jovanovich, 40, formerly served as executive vice president of the Orlando-based publishing and insurance company. He succeeds Ralph D. Caulo, 54, whose resignation is effective Dec. 31. Caulo has resigned to ``enter other ventures in central Florida and in Austin and San Antonio, Texas,'' the company said Wednesday. William Jovanovich, 69, remains as chairman of the board of HBJ. Caulo's position at the publishing gaint has appeared in jeopardy since last summer, when HBJ announced plans to sell its six theme parks. The company also said at the time that it would allow Caulo to leave his post to manage the parks. But an HBJ executive close to sale negotiations told the Orlando Sentinel that Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc., which bought the parks in November for $1.1 billion, wanted to employ its own park executive. William Jovanovich, the Sentinel reported in Thursday's editions, sought to oust Caulo in order to place his son Peter in a better position to later assume leadership of the company. Caulo could not be immediately reached for comment. In 1987, HBJ assumed nearly $3 billion in debt to fend off a takeover bid by British press mogul Robert Maxwell. The sale last month of its theme parks, including four Sea World parks, to Anheuser-Busch was made to help pay off that debt. With the sale, HBJ reduced its debt by about $930 million to about $1.63 billion, analysts say. Elizabeth Bramwell, an analyst at Gabelli & Co., a New York brokerage, said she believes Jovanovich's move to the HBJ presidency ``is a constructive move'' that signals a determination to turn the company's full attention to publishing, its core business. ``They took their eye off the eight-ball and expense in publishing and expenses this year got out of control,'' Bramwell said. Ivan Obolensky, senior vice president at Josephthal & Co., another New York brokerage, expressed doubt that the promotion of Peter Jovanovich will make a big difference at HBJ. ``It's not a big change; it's the leopard changing its spots.'' Obolensky said he is concerned that HBJ remains vulnerable to a hostile takeover. In his new position, Peter Jovanovich will supervise HBJ's elementary and secondary school publishing. For the past five years he has managed HBJ's other publishing businesses, including university, medical, scientific and trade books, and fiction and non-fiction titles. The younger Jovanovich joined HBJ in 1980 after working for Macmillian Inc., another publishing house.
